newsitem.title: CHINA: Russia's Nemtsov says wants more trade with China.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Nemtsov says wants more trade with China.

text.p: Russian First Deputy Prime Minister Boris Nemtsov urged an expansion of trade in talks with Chinese officials on Tuesday, saying the current level was inadequate.
Nemtsov, who is also minister of fuel and energy, was leading a delegation of nuclear energy and trade officials to prepare for a visit by Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin later this week.
The delegation was expected to hammer out details of a deal for a multi-billion dollar project that could exploit Siberian natural gas to meet China's growing demand for energy, diplomats have said.
Chernomyrdin is scheduled to arrive in Beijing on Thursday for a three-day visit during which he is expected to sign the natural gas agreement, they said.
In talks with Chinese Vice Premier Li Lanqing, Nemtsov urged an expansion of bilateral trade, the Xinhua news agency said.
The current trade volume of less than $7.0 billion a year was too low and did not correspond to the size of the two countries, Nemtsov was quoted as telling Li.

Trade between the two neighbours was about $6.8 billion last year, with a surplus in China's favour. Beijing estimates that figure could reach $8-10 billion in 1997 and says it hopes the total will hit $20 billion by the year 2000.
Chernomyrdin is to meet his Chinese counterpart Li Peng on June 27 after a stopover in Shenzhen, near the British territory of Hong Kong.

His visit is the latest in a string of high-level official exchanges between the two giant neighbours, following a trip to Moscow by Chinese President Jiang Zemin in April and a journey to China last spring by Russian President Boris Yeltsin.
China once was a net oil exporter but speedy economic growth has fuelled demand for energy, with Chinese officials predicting oil imports could reach an annual 50 million tonnes by the year 2000.

Among other energy-related deals, a Russian consortium is vying for a contract to supply China with 14 generators with a total installed capacity of 9,800 megawatts for the gargantuan Three Gorges dam on the Yangtze River.

Beijing and Moscow have also agreed to build a multi-billion dollar nuclear power plant in China's eastern province of Jiangsu, which Russia has offered to finance with $2 billion worth of low-interest loans.
Sino-Russian ties have gradually warmed since 1989 when the two sides formally mended relations strained after the two communist giants struggled for leadership of the socialist world in the 1960s.
Both have said they want to see an improvement in economic ties to match gains on the political front.
